titleStmt.title: By the King Iames by the grace of God, king of England, Scotland, France and Ireland ... : whereas our late sister ... Elizabeth late queen of England by her letters patents bearing date at Westminster the xiii. day of Iuly, in the xxxvi. yeere of her raigne ...
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1603-1625 : James I)

titleStmt.title: By the King Iames by the grace of God, king of England, Scotland, France and Ireland ... : whereas our late sister ... Elizabeth late queen of England by her letters patents bearing date at Westminster the xiii. day of Iuly, in the xxxvi. yeere of her raigne ...
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1603-1625 : James I)
James I, King of England, 1566-1625.

notesStmt.note: For granting 21-year patent to the Duke of Lenox, for the office of King's Alnager, collector of the subsidy on wool cloth.
Other title information from first 5 lines of text.
"Witnesse Our selfe at Westminster, the sixteenth day of September, in the third yeere of Our Reigne of England, Fraunce and Ireland, and of Scotland the nine and thirtieth."
Signed: Clapham. Per bre. depriuat. Sigil.
Reproduction of original in: Society of Antiquaries.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ‚ùß By the King.

opener.signed: IAMES, by the grace of God, king of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, defender of the Faith, &c.
opener.salute: To al men to whom the≈øe Our pre≈øent Letters ≈øhall come, Greeting.

div.p:
The recitail of the late Queenes Letters Patents by her granted to Sir George Delues and William Fitz-william. Wheras our late Si≈øter of famous Memorie, Elizabeth late Queen of England, by her Letters Patents, bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter the xiii. day of Iuly, in the xxxvi. yeere of her Raigne: Reciting thereby, that whereas it had beene alwayes of ancient time, and ≈øo from time to time thought and found very profitable for the common wealth of this Realme, That all manner woollen cloth made within this ≈øame Realme to be ≈øold, ≈øhould be ≈øearched, mea≈øured and ≈øealed by the Alnagers of her Progenitors, and of her Highnes being Officers to that purpo≈øe, appointed to the intent, a≈øwell that no per≈øon ≈øhould bee deceiued, by buying deceitfull woollen cloth vnduely made, As al≈øo that by rea≈øon of the true making of the ≈øaid woollen Cloth, the making thereof might be continued: And the people of this Realme therby the better ≈øet on worke. Thought fit and rea≈øonable that a rea≈øonable fee ≈øhould bee paid to the Alnager for his paines. And that it had likewi≈øe beene thought and found very rea≈øonable and nece≈ø≈øary, that a rea≈øonable fee ≈øhould be paide vnto the ≈øaide Alnager, for his paines in that behalfe: And that a Sub≈øidie ≈øhould be paid for the ≈øaid Clothes, vnto her ≈øaid Progenitors, and her Highnes. And to that end, that diuers Acts of Parliaments and Ordinances, had beene made in the time of her Progenitors, and were then in force. And that for a≈ømuch as then of late yeeres, diuers ≈øorts of woollen Clothes, and other commodities commonly called double, middle and ≈øingle Bayes, Ra≈øhe, or Stammell of Florence ≈øort, Serge of Frence ≈øort, Sayes of Flaunders ≈øort, Narrow wor≈øteeds, Grograynes, Mockadoes of euery ≈øortes, Plumets, Freezadoes, Carrel, Fu≈øtian of Naples, Blankets, called Spanni≈øh Rugges, Knitho≈øe of wor≈øted yarne, and of all ≈øorts of new Draperies, and other new Stuffes, and commodities, then made of wooll onely, or mo≈øt part of wooll, had been chiefly deui≈øed, & made within her Realme of England by Strangers, & Aliens borne, that re≈øorted into this Realme. That all new ≈øorts of Draperies by Statutes ought to be ≈øearched, weighed and ≈øealed and charged with a Sub≈øidie in ≈øuch ≈øort as other woollen clothes. And that then of later time, the making was v≈øed in diuers places within this Realme, a≈øwell by the ≈øaide ≈øtrangers, as by her Subiects, which new ≈øortes of Draperies, and woollen commoditities with all other like that ≈øhould be therafter inuented, or deui≈øed to be made wholly, or mo≈øt part of wooll within this Realme, ought by the Statutes, Lawes and Ordinances of this Realme, and by the true meaning and equitie of the ≈øame, to be ≈øearched and mea≈øured or weighed, and ≈øealed, and to be charged with a Sub≈øidie, to be paide to her Maie≈øtie, her heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors in ≈øuch ≈øort, as other woollen clothes before that time ≈øold or made within this Realme of England: had beene and ought to be. And that no Officer or Officers were e≈øpecially appointed, either to the ≈øearching, mea≈øuring, weighing and ≈øealing of the ≈øaid new Draperies, or to the collection of the ≈øaid Sub≈øidie, vntill that then of late yeeres. her tru≈øtie ≈øeruants, Sir George Delues, Knight, and William Fitz william, two other Maie≈øties Gentlemen Pentioners, had beene thereunto appointed, by her ≈øeuerall Lea≈øes, which then were expired and determined: By rea≈øon whereof, not onely the ≈øaid newly deui≈øed Clothes, and woollen commodities had wanted, and might againe want the due allowance that ought to haue beene, and was by the ≈øealing thereof, to the daunger of the buyers of the ≈øame. But al≈øo that her ≈øaid late Maie≈øtie had likewi≈øe wanted and might againe want the Sub≈øidy of the ≈øame to her great lo≈ø≈øe. Her Maie≈øties plea≈øure that all the new ≈øorts of Draperies and Clothes ≈øhould at all times bee ≈øurueyed, mea≈øured, weighed, tried and ≈øealed, &c. Wherefore minding and intending redre≈ø≈øe and remedie to bee had in that behalfe, her Maie≈øtie then thought good, and her will and plea≈øure had beene ≈øignified by her former Letters Patents, and then was that all the ≈øaid new ≈øortes of Draperies, and Clothes aboue particularly ≈øpecified and expre≈ø≈øed, and euery of them made, & to be made, within this her Realme of England, and all other ≈øorts of woollen Clothes, new Draperies, made and to be made within this ≈øaid Realme, of wooll, or the mo≈øt part of wooll, which in the time of her Raigne, or late before had not beene v≈øu≈øually made within this ≈øaid Realme of England, or for the which the ≈øaid Alnagers had not commonly v≈øed before that time, to make any ≈øearch, mea≈øure, weighing, marking or ≈øealing, or to take the ≈øaid Sub≈øidie, ≈øhould at all times from thencefoorth be ≈øurueyed, mea≈øured, weighed, tryed and ≈øealed by ≈øuch per≈øon and per≈øons, as by the Lord Trea≈øurer of England for the time being, ≈øhould be from time to time appointed. That the ≈øub≈øidie ≈øhould bee leuied and payd for the ≈øame from thencefoorth. And that the ≈øaid Sub≈øidie ≈øhould be leuied and paide for the ≈øame, from thencefoorth. And that for a≈ømuch, as her ≈øaid tru≈øtie ≈øeruants Sir George Delues, and William Fitz-william, & either of them Alnager & Alnagers of the ≈øaid new Draperies, and Collectors of the ≈øaid Sub≈øidie of the ≈øame, for and during the ≈øpace of xxi. yeeres, to commence and beginne at the Fea≈øt of the Natiuitie of S. Iohn Bapti≈øt then la≈øt pa≈øt before the date of the ≈øame Letters Patents by them≈øelues their Deputies and A≈ø≈øignes. The Queens Maie≈øties authoritie to her Alnagers to weigh, mea≈øure, trye, ≈øearch and ≈øeale or marke all the new ≈øorts of draperies. And her ≈øaid Maie≈øtie did thereby, for her, her heyres, and Succe≈ø≈øors, giue and graunt vnto the ≈øaid Sir George Delues and William Fitz-william, their Executors, Admini≈øtrators, and A≈ø≈øignes, and euery of them, full power and authoritie to weigh, mea≈øure, trie, ≈øearch and ≈øeale, or marke, all and ≈øingular the ≈øaid double, middle, and ≈øingle Bayes, Ra≈øhe, or Stammell of Florence ≈øort, Serge of the French ≈øort Sayes of the Flanders ≈øort, Narrow Wor≈øteeds, Grograynes, Mockadoes of euery ≈øort, Plummets, Freezadoes, Carrell, Fu≈øtians, called Fu≈øtians of Naples, Blankets, called Spani≈øh Rugges, Knit-ho≈øe, and all and euery other new ≈øorts of Draperies or Clothes, and other Stuffes made or to be made only, or mo≈øt part of wooll within this Realme of England, which in the time of her Raigne or late before, had not beene v≈øually made within this ≈øaid Realme of England, or for, or of the which the ≈øaid Alnagers for the time being, had not commonly before that
time v≈øed, to make any ≈øearch, mea≈øure, weighing, marking, or ≈øealing, or to take the ≈øayd Sub≈øidies. To haue and to hold during the ≈øpace of 21. yeeres. To haue and to hold to them the ≈øame from the fea≈øt of the Natiuitie of Saint Iohn Bapti≈øt then la≈øt pa≈øt, for and during the ≈øpace of one and twenty yeeres, from thence next en≈øuing, with authoritie and full power to ≈øeale and marke ≈øuch of the ≈øayd Draperies and ≈øtuffes as were and ≈øhould be lawfully and truely made, And with ≈øuch ≈øeale and ≈øeales or other marke, as by her High Trea≈øurer of England for the time being, ≈øhould bee deliuered and appointed to them for the purpo≈øe.

Her Maie≈øty willed they ≈øhuld be reputed, taken and called Alnagers of the new draperies, &c.And whereas al≈øo, her ≈øaid Maie≈øtie, by her ≈øaid Letters Patents, did for her, her Heyres & Succe≈ø≈øors, will and graunt that during the ≈øaid Tearme of one and twentie yeares, they ≈øhould bee reputed, taken and called Alnagers, Sealers, Searchers and Viewers of the new Draperies, and woollen commodities made, and to be made within this ≈øaid realme, and the Collectors of the Sub≈øidies and duties thereof. Her Maie≈øties command that at the new draperies which were put to ≈øale, ≈øhould be mea≈øured, tried, ≈øearched and weighed, and ≈øuch as were found good and marchantable ≈øhould bee ≈øealed And whereas al≈øo her Highne≈ø≈øe did further of her certeine knowledge and meere motion graunt will and commaund, That euery of the ≈øaide Frezadoes, double, middle, and ≈øingle Baies, Ra≈øh, or Stamel of Florence ≈øort, Serdge of the French ≈øort, Wor≈øteds, Grograines, Mockadoes, of euery ≈øort, Plumet, Carrels, Fu≈øtians, called Fu≈øtian of Naples, Buffins, Blankets called Spani≈øh Rugges, knit ho≈øe of Wor≈øted yarne, Iar≈øey yarne or other woollen, made and to bee made, within this ≈øaid Realme to be put to ≈øale, and all other of the ≈øayd Draperies, and ≈øtuffes, made & to be made within the ≈øame Realme of England, being all, or the mo≈øt part of Wooll as afore≈øaid, to be put to ≈øale, ≈øhould be mea≈øured, ≈øearched, weighed, and tried, by the ≈øaid Sir George Delues, and William Fitz william and their Executors Deputies and A≈ø≈øignes, or by ≈øome or one of them, (during the ≈øayd ≈øpace of twentie and one yeeres,) before the ≈øame ≈øhould bee put to ≈øale, And that all ≈øuch of the ≈øame as ≈øhould be found to be good Lawfull and Marchantable ware ≈øhould be ≈øealed or marked by them their Deputies, Factors or A≈ø≈øignes, by a Seale or marke to them to be appointed by the ≈øayd high Trea≈øurer of England as afore≈øayd. All ≈øuch draperies and ≈øtuffes being found to be defectiue or deceiptfully made or wrought, ≈øhuld be cut and lagged to the intent no per≈øons ≈øhould be deceiued thereby. And that ≈øuch of the ≈øame Draperies and ≈øtuffes, as ≈øhould be found by them their Deputies and Mini≈øters, Factors or A≈ø≈øignes or any of them, to be defectiue or deceitfully made or brought ≈øhould bee cut and Iagged at both the ends, thereby to note the ≈øame defect and default without any ≈øeale, or other marke to be put to the ≈øame, to the intent that no per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhould be deceiued thereby. And whereas al≈øo her Maie≈øtie, by her ≈øayd Letters Patents, Recyting further that fora≈ømuch as no certaine rate or ≈øumme of money was before the ≈øayd graunt then tofore made to the ≈øaid Sir George Delues and William Fitz-william as afore≈øaid taken, or payd to her ≈øayd Maie≈øtie, or certainly ≈øet downe for the mea≈øuring, ≈øearching, trying and Sub≈øidies of the ≈øayde Draperies and other ≈øtuffes as afore≈øayd: the Contents whereof were diuers, did ≈øignifie her will and plea≈øure, to bee as by her ≈øayd former graunts her ≈øayd Maie≈øtie had before ≈øignified, viz. That where, by her lawes and Statutes there had bene and then was allowed due and payd for the ≈øayde Sub≈øidie to her ≈øayde Maie≈øtie for euery broad Clothe, which by the Statute of this Realme ought to weigh three≈øcore and foure pounds, the ≈øumme of 4 d. in money fo ‚Ä¢ euery broad cloth which by Statute ought to weigh 64 pound weight, and 2. d. for euery halfe cloth. foure pence in money, for euery halfe of ≈øuch Cloth two pence in money which amounteth to one farthing for euery foure pound weight of the ≈øame Cloth. For mea≈øuring, ≈øearching, and ≈øealing of euery whole cloth, ob and for euery halfe cloth a farthing. And for the mea≈øuring, ≈øearching and ≈øealing of euery whole Cloth, one halfe peny to the Alnager for his fee, and for euery halfe Cloth one farthing. That therefore the Rates and ≈øummes of money as well for the Sub≈øidie, as for the Alnage of the ≈øayd new Draperies, and other new wollen commodities particularly and otherwi≈øe ≈øpecified, or contained in a Schedule vnto the ≈øaid Letters Patents annexed, ≈øhould bee paid allowed and leuied from thencefoorth, of and for euery of the ≈øayd new Draperies which was found to agree or not much to differ in proportion, from the Rates and Duties, ≈øet payd and allowed then-tofore for broad wollen Cloathes. And that if any per≈øon or per≈øons of what e≈øtate or degree ≈øoeuer he or they ≈øhould bee, did ≈øell or put to ≈øale, or cau≈øe to be ≈øold or put to ≈øale, or ≈øhould fraught or imbarque or cau≈øe to be ≈øhipped, fraughted, or imbarqued any of the new ≈øaid Draperies, or wollen CoÃÑmodities, or ≈øuch ≈øtuffes as is afore≈øaid in the ≈øaid Letters Patents authori≈øed to be ≈øearched, to the intent to Tran≈øport the ≈øame to be put to ≈øale before the ≈øame ≈øhould bee ≈øearched, mea≈øured, weighed, and ≈øealed by her Maie≈øties ≈øayd Officers, or their A≈ø≈øignes as afore≈øayd, And the fees and Sub≈øidies afore≈øayd therefore payd or agreed for, That then and ≈øo often, as hee, ≈øhe, or they ≈øo putting to ≈øale, ≈øhipping, lading, fraughting or imbarquing the ≈øame ≈øhould To forfeyt xx.s. for vttering or putting to ≈øale, ≈øhipping, lading, or fraughting euerie piece before it were fir≈øt ≈øearched, mea≈øured and ≈øealed. forfeit and pay for euery piece thereof ≈øo put to ≈øale or offered to bee put to ≈øale, ≈øhipped, fraughted or imbarqued, twenty ≈øhillings of lawfull money of England. And where al≈øo her ≈øayd late Maie≈øty by her ≈øayd Letters Patents of her further e≈øpeciall grace, meere motion and certaine knowledge did demi≈øe and grant to farme, to the ≈øaid Sir George Delues, and William Fitz-william their Executors and A≈ø≈øignes, the Sub≈øidies, ≈øummes and duties limitted by the ≈øayd Letters Pattents to be payd of or for all and euery the ≈øaid new Draperies and other woollen Commodities afore≈øayd, And all and euery the forfeytures afore ≈øayd, as to her Maie≈øty, her Heires and Succe≈ø≈øors, ≈øhould grow an≈øwerable or due: To haue and to hold the ≈øayd Sub≈øidie, ≈øummes, duties and forfeytures to the ≈øayd Sir George Delues, and William Fitz-william their Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øignes, from the fea≈øt of the Natiuitie of Saint Iohn Bapti≈øt, then la≈øt pa≈øt before the date of the ≈øayde Letters Patents vnto the end and terme of one and twenty yeeres, from thence, next en≈øuing, and fully to be Compleat and ended, &c.

The woolles of the Realme from time to time conuerted not onely into ≈øtuffes, draperies and commodities: but al≈øo into diuers other new ≈øorts of ≈øtuffes, not made within this Realme at the time of her Maie≈øties grant to Sir George Delues, & William Fitz-william, to the great lo≈ø≈øe of his Maie≈øties Cu≈øtomes and Sub≈øidies in former times payd for the woolles of this Land tran≈øported, &c.And whereas we perceiuing the Woolles of this Realme to be from time to time conuerted not onely into the Stuffes, Draperies, & Commodities aboue mentioned, but al≈øo into diuers other new ≈øortes of Stuffes, Draperies and Commodities not made within this Realme, at the time of the making of the ≈øayde ≈øeuerall Lea≈øes or grants to the ≈øayd Sir George Delues, and William Fitz-william, to Our great lo≈ø≈øe in the Cu≈øtomes and Sub≈øidies, in former times payd to diuers of Our Progenitors, for the Woolles of this Land tran≈øported into the parts beyond the Seas, and that the ≈øame new inuentions are likely more and more to increa≈øe: And perceiuing al≈øo that diuers Clothiers heretofore v≈øing to make broad Clothes, haue changed their Loomes, and ≈øpinnings to the making of the ≈øame new inuentions, And that it is to bee pre≈øumed that others will doe the like: The game and returne of ≈øuch new Draperies and late inuented ≈øtuffes, and Commodities, made of Wooll, or part of Wooll comparing weight to weight being farre greater and quicker, and the trade thereof exerci≈øed with le≈ø≈øe ≈øtocke & charge then is requi≈øite to the making of broad Clothes, which would turne greatly to Our lo≈ø≈øe, if as well a Sub≈øidie ≈øhould not be payd and an≈øwered vnto Vs for the ≈øaid new Inuentions as for broad Clothes. We well approuing our ≈øayd Si≈øters care and proui≈øion that proportionable ≈øummes ≈øhould be paid for the Sub≈øidie and Alnage of the ≈øayd new and later Inuentions, according to the rate of the Sub≈øidie and Alnage payd for broad Cloth: are fully minded and purpo≈øed, And doe by the≈øe pre≈øents appoint, That as by the Lawes and Statutes of this Realme, there hath beene and now is allowed due and payd to Vs for the Sub≈øidie of euery broad Cloth made to bee ≈øold, which by the Statutes of this Realme ought to weigh three≈øcore and foure pounds, The ≈øumme of foure pence in money, And for euery halfe of ≈øuch Cloth two pence in money which amounteth to one farthing for euery foure pound weight of the ≈øame Clothe. And for the mea≈øuring, ≈øearching, and ≈øealing of euery whole broad Clothe made to be ≈øold which by the Statutes of this Realme ought to containe in length foure and twenty yards, one halfe penny to the Alnager for his Fee, and for euery halfe of ≈øuch Cloth one farthing, ≈øo from henceforth for euery three≈øcore and foure pound weight of the ≈øayd 4. d. for euerie 64. pound weight of the ≈øaid Freezadoes according and ≈øo ratably for euery ≈øuch king of new draperies Freezadoes, double, middle & ≈øingles Bayes, Ra≈øh, or Stamel of Florence ≈øort, Serdge of French ≈øort, Sayes of the Flaunders ≈øort, Narrow Wor≈øteds, Valentia, Grograines,
and Grograines of all ≈øorts,The names of ≈øtuffes belonging to the new draperie. Mockadoes of euery ≈øort, Plummets, Carrell, Fu≈øtians, and Fu≈øtian called Fu≈øtian of Naples, Buffins of all ≈øorts, Blankets, called Spani≈øh Rugges, knit ho≈øe of Woor≈øted yarne, Iar≈øey yarne or other woollen yarne, And for euery three≈øcore and foure pound weight of all ≈øorts of the woollen and party woollen Clothes, ≈øtuffes, & Commodities of Arras, Tape≈ø≈øary or Tapi≈øtry, Abrecetta, Bewpars, Boratoes, Boulters, Blanckets, Bu≈øteans, Bombacies, Brocatellaes, Calimancoes, Cangeans, changeable Canuas, ChannoÃÑ clothes, Chamblets, Car≈øa, Cri≈øpe, Crewel, Carpetings, Couerlets, Curles, Dornix, Duraunces, Dama≈øks Demicie, Faire a farre off, Fu≈øtenadoes of all ≈øorts, Fringe, Felts, Flannels, Garterings, Gyrthes, Girdlings, knit wa≈øtcotes, knit petticotes, knit ≈øleeues, knit Gloues, knit Caps, knit Coyfes, knit Hats, knit ≈øocks, Lyon Ra≈ø≈øhes, Lacyngs, Lyncy Wol≈øeys, Ma≈ø≈øalina, Macrels, Moheres, Mountaines, Mounkes Clothes, Motleis, Minikins, O≈øetts, Olyots, His Maie≈øties command that all new Draperies within the Realm of England and Dominion of Wales, ≈øhall be mea≈øured, ≈øearched, weighed, and tried by the ≈øaid Duke, his depu. or a≈ø≈øig or his or their depu. or a≈ø≈øig.And we doe further of our certaine knowledge and meere motion graunt, will and commaund, that euery of the ≈øayd clothes, ≈øtuffes, draperies and commodities by what≈øoeuer name or names, they are, or ≈øhall bee knowen, or called, made, and hereafter to be made within this our Realme of England, and Dominion of Wales, (except before excepted) to be put to ≈øale. And being found to be good lawfull and marchantable, to be ≈øealed or marked.And that all ≈øuch of the ≈øame as ≈øhall be found to be good, lawfull and marchantable ware, ≈øhall be ≈øealed or marked by our ≈øaid Alnager, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators, Deputies, and A≈ø≈øignes, or his or their Deputie or Deputies, by and with a ≈øeale or marke to him or them to be appointed by our ≈øaid high Trea≈øurer of England as afore≈øaid. His Maie≈øties plea≈øure that no per≈øon ≈øhall ≈øell, ≈øet, ≈øend, or put to ≈øale, or Shippe, Fraight or imbarke any the ≈øaid new Draperies to the intent to tran≈øport the ≈øame to be put to ≈øale before they be ≈øearched, mea≈øured, weighed & ≈øealed or marked by the Alnager his exec. admin. depu or a≈ø≈øig. and the Fees and Sub≈øidies paid therefore or agreed for, vpon paine of forf ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ iture of 20.5. for euery ≈øuch peece of ≈øtuffe. And that ≈øuch of the ≈øame Clothes, Draperies, Stuffes and Commodities as afore≈øaide, as ≈øhall bee found by our ≈øaide Alnager, his Deputies, Mini≈øters, Factors or A≈ø≈øignes, or his or their Deputie or Deputies, or any of them, to be Defectiue or Deceitfuly made or wrought, ≈øhall bee by him or them cut and iagged at both the ends, thereby to note the ≈øame defect and default without any ≈øeale or other marke to be put to the ≈øame, to the intent that no per≈øon or per≈øons be deceiued thereby.

Authoritie that all ≈øuch of the ≈øame clothes Draperies, Stuffes being found to be defectiue or deceitfully made or wrought ≈øhould be cut and iagged at both ends without any ≈øeale thereto, to the intent that no per≈øons be deceiued thereby.And our will and plea≈øure is, that if any per≈øon or per≈øons of what e≈øtate or degree ≈øoeuer, hee or they bee of, doe or ≈øhall ≈øell, ≈øet, ≈øend, or put to ≈øale, or cau≈øe to bee ≈øold, ≈øent, ≈øet, or put to ≈øale, or doe or ≈øhall Fraught, or Imbarque, or cau≈øe to bee Shipped, Fraughted, or Imbarqued, any of the ≈øaid Clothes, Stuffes, Draperies and Commodities, or any other ≈øuch like, as is afor≈øaid herein authori≈øed to be ≈øearched and ≈øealed, to the intent to tran≈øport the ≈øame to be put to ≈øale, before the ≈øame ≈øhall be ≈øearched, mea≈øured, weighed and ≈øealed, or marked by our ≈øaid Officer, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators, Deputies or A≈ø≈øignes as afore≈øaid, and the Fees and Sub≈øidies, afore≈øaid therefore payed or agreed for, That then and ≈øo often, hee, ≈øhee, or they, ≈øo ≈øelling, ≈øending, ≈øetting or putting to ≈øale, Shipping, Lading, Fraughting or Imbarking the ≈øame, ≈øhall forfeite and pay for euery peece thereof, ≈øo ≈øold, ≈øent, ≈øet or put to ≈øale, or offered to be put to ≈øale, Shipped, Fraughted, or Embarqued, twentie ≈øhillings of lawfull money of England.

His Maie≈øties demi≈øe for 21. yeeres to the Duke, of all Sub≈øidies, ≈øummes & duties, limited to be paid for the new Draperies & the moietie of all and euery the forfeitures.And further, know ye that of Our further e≈øpeciall grace, certaine knowledge and meere motion, we haue demi≈øed and granted, and by the≈øe pre≈øents doe demi≈øe and grant to farme to the ≈øayd Lodowicke Duke of Lenox, his executors, admini≈øtrators, and A≈ø≈øignes, the ≈øub≈øidies, ≈øummes and dueties, limitted by the≈øe pre≈øents, to bee payd of, or for all and euery the ≈øayd new Draperies, ≈øtuffes and other woollen commodities, afore≈øayd made and to be made within this our Realme of England and dominion of Wales (except before excepted,) and the Moyetie of all and euery the forfeyture and forfeytures afore≈øayd, as to Vs Our Heyres and Succe≈ø≈øours due or ≈øhall grow an≈øwerable or due. To haue and to hold the ≈øayd Sub≈øidie, ≈øummes, duties and moyeties of forfeytures, of all and euery the ≈øayd Clothes, ≈øtuffes, draperies and commodities vnto the ≈øayd Lodowicke Duke of Lenox, his executors, admini≈øtrators and a≈ø≈øignes from the ≈øayd Fea≈øt of S. Michael the Archangel la≈øt pa≈øt, vnto the end and terme of one and twenty yeeres, from thence next en≈øuing, and fully to be complete and ended.

The ≈øame new Draperies, Stuffes and commodities being once ≈øearched, mea≈øured & ≈øealed or marked by the Duke, or his depu. ≈øeruants or a≈ø≈øig. ≈øhall not any more be ≈øearched, mea≈øured, ≈øealed, or marked by any other.And further, our will and plea≈øure is, and we doe by the≈øe pre≈øents graunt, That what≈øoeuer of the ≈øayd new Draperies, ≈øtuffes, and commodities, ≈øhall be by the ≈øayd Lodowicke Duke of Lenox, his deputies, ≈øeruants, or a≈ø≈øignes, or by any of them ≈øearched, mea≈øured and ≈øealed, or marked in forme afore≈øayd, the ≈øame ≈øhal not afterwards for the ≈øame cau≈øe be by any other our Officers, Mini≈øters or ≈øubiects, within this our realme of England or Dominion of Wales (except before excepted) any more ≈øearched, mea≈øured, ≈øealed or marked, but that the owners of the ≈øame may frankly and freely ≈øell, vtter or marchandize the ≈øame to any per≈øon or per≈øons, without any maner of other charge, vexation, impeachment, mole≈øtation or interruption what≈øoeuer, for or concerning the ≈øaid Sub≈øidie and alnage before expre≈ø≈øed.

in euery or any of the Counties, Cities, Townes corporate, Boroughs, Townes, Villages and Hamlets within this our Realme of England, and dominion of Wales (except before excepted) ≈øuch and ≈øo many ≈øufficient ≈øub≈øtitutes, and deput ‚Ä¢ es, for the mea≈øuring, ≈øearching, viewing, weighing, marking and ≈øealing of all ≈øuch Clothes, Draperies, ≈øtuffes and commodities, as are heerein or heereby appointed, or authori≈øed to be mea≈øured, ≈øearched, viewed, weighed, marked or ≈øealed; And for the collection and gathering of the ≈øayd ≈øub≈øidies and Alnage, as by the ≈øayd Lodowicke Duke of Lenox, his executors, admini≈øtrators or a≈ø≈øignes ≈øhall be thought meete and conuenient, and to the ende and intent, to auoyd all fraudes and deceits, and all concealements of, in, and about the Premi≈ø≈øes.

Authoritie at all rea≈øonable times, to enter into all places what≈øoeuer, to ≈øearch, ≈øee and trie, &c. for vs our heyres and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, vnto the ≈øayd Lodowicke Duke of Lenox, his executors, admini≈øtrators and a≈ø≈øignes, and his and their Deputie and Deputies, and euery of them, full power and and Dominion of Wales, (except before excepted) and to ≈øearch, ≈øee, trie and examine, if any of the ≈øayd Clothes, ≈øtuffes, Draperies, or Commodities, and all other the ≈øayd new draperies, & new them found to be ≈øent, put, or ≈øet to ≈øale, ≈øhipped or imbarqued, not marqued or ≈øealed as afore≈øaid, to ≈øeize, keepe, and retaine, till the forfeiture and forfeytures afore≈øayd, and euery of and Our Court of Exchequer.

That if any per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhal re≈øi≈øt or deny any ≈øearch, to forfeit for euery ≈øuch default, 10. lib.And that if any per≈øon or per≈øons ≈øhall re≈øi≈øt or denie any ≈øuch ≈øearch or ≈øearches by Our ≈øayd Alnager, his Officers, Deputies or a≈ø≈øignes, or his or their deputies or a≈ø≈øignes, from time to time to be made, That then he, ≈øhee, or they making re≈øi≈øtance or deniall, ≈øhall for euery ≈øuch default, forfeyt and pay to Vs and Our Heires and Succe≈ø≈øors, ten pounds of lawfull Engli≈øh money.

Expre≈ø≈øe command that no Cu≈øtomers, Comptrolers, or Collectors, of the Sub≈øidies of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ onnage or pondage, „Äà‚óä„Äâ their ‚Ä¢ ffi
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ r doe take any ‚Ä¢ utie, receiue any cu≈øt ‚Ä¢ me, or m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ e com ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ they ‚Ä¢ e ≈øeale ‚Ä¢ , or marked by the Alnager or his Deputies.And We doe heereby further wil and Command that none of our Cu≈øtomers, Comptrollers, or Collectors of Our Sub≈øidies of Tonnage or Pondage in any Our Cu≈øtome-hou≈øes in any Port within our Realme of England or Dominion of Wales (except before excepted) or of any of Our Farmers of the ≈øame Cu≈øtomes or Sub≈øidies, of Tonnage or Pondage, or any of their Officer or Officers, doe from hencefoorth, take any entrie or receiue any Cu≈øtome or Sub≈øidie, or make any compo≈øition for any Cu≈øtome or Sub≈øidie for any the ≈øayd Clothes, ≈øtuffes, Draperies or Commodities what≈øoeuer made or hereafter to be made within our Realme of England and dominion of Wales, (except before excepted) vnle≈ø≈øe they be ≈øealed or marked by our ≈øayd Alnager, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øignes, or his or their Deputie or Deputies, or one of them with the Seale or marke thereunto ordained.

His Maie≈øties expre≈ø≈øe commandement to all, &c. to be aidin ‚Ä¢ and a≈ø≈øi≈øting in the execution of this office, vpon pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ e of his Highnes di≈øplea≈øure and as they will an≈øwere the contrarie at their perils.And our further will and plea≈øure is, and we doe ≈øtraightly Charge and Command, all and euery Maiors, Sheriffes, Bailiffes, Iu≈øtices of Peace, head Boroughs, Con≈øtables, and other Our Officers, Mini≈øters, and Subiects what≈øoeuer, That they ayde and a≈ø≈øi≈øt, the ≈øaid Lodowicke Duke of Lenox his Executors, Admini≈øtrators and A≈ø≈øignes, and his or their Deputie or Deputies, and euery of them, in and by all lawfull meanes, and wayes what≈øoeuer for the due execution of the fore≈øayd Offices, and the≈øe Our Letters Patents, according to the forme, force, and effect thereof, as they tender Our plea≈øure, and will an≈øwere to the contrary at their perils.

Authoritie to the lord Trea≈øurer of England for the time being, to make new and further ordinances, and to graunt command for the further aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in the execution of the ≈øaid office and his Maie≈øties letters Patents.And further of Our certaine knowledge, and meere motion, wee grant will and Command, that if there ≈øhall want any ≈øufficient Act, meane, or thing, to giue ≈øufficient power and authoritie to Our ≈øayd Officer his Executors, Admini≈øtrators, Deputies, and A≈ø≈øignes, and to the Deputies and A≈ø≈øignes of euery of them, to doe, performe and execute all and euery or any thing mentioned in the≈øe pre≈øents, according to the true meaning and effect thereof, for the aduancement of the ≈øayde Office, and Farme which is meant to Our ≈øpeciall benefit: That the Lord Trea≈øurer of England for the time being, ≈øhall from time to time haue power and authoritie to make new and further Ordinances, and to graunt Commi≈ø≈øions for the further ayde, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of our ≈øayd Cou≈øin Lodowicke Duke of Lenox, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators, Deputies, and A≈ø≈øignes, in and for the full Execution and performance of the ≈øayd Offices and of the≈øe Our Letters Patents.

In witne≈ø≈øe whereof Wee haue cau≈øed the≈øe Our Letters to be made Patents. Witne≈ø≈øe Our ≈øelfe at We≈øtmin≈øter, the ≈øixteenth day of September, in the third yeere of Our Reigne of England, Fraunce, and Ireland, and of Scotland the nine and thirtieth.

closer.signed: Clapham. Per bre. de priuat. Sigil.
